clinical_summary.presenting_complaints: Patient presented to emergency department with acute onset severe abdominal pain in right lower quadrant for past 12 hours. Pain started periumbilically and migrated to right iliac fossa. Associated with nausea, vomiting (3 episodes), and fever (101°F). Pain aggravated by movement and coughing.
clinical_summary.medical_history: No significant past medical history. No chronic illnesses. No known drug allergies. No previous surgeries.
clinical_summary.preop_examination:
Physical Examination: Temperature 101.2°F, Pulse 110/min, BP 120/80 mmHg. Abdomen: Tenderness and guarding in right iliac fossa, positive McBurney's point tenderness, positive Rovsing's sign. Rebound tenderness present.

USG Abdomen (09/10/2025): Dilated appendix (9mm diameter) with surrounding fluid collection suggestive of perforation and localized peritonitis.

Blood Investigations: TLC 18,500/cumm (elevated), Neutrophils 85%, CRP 45 mg/L (elevated). Serum Electrolytes and Renal Function: Within normal limits.
preop_investigations: USG Abdomen: Perforated appendicitis with localized peritonitis

diagnosis.final_diagnosis: Post-operative status following emergency laparoscopic appendectomy for perforated appendicitis with localized peritonitis

procedure.name: Emergency Laparoscopic Appendectomy with Peritoneal Lavage and Drain Placement
procedure.technique: Standard 3-port laparoscopic technique. Intraoperative findings revealed perforated appendix with localized abscess formation (approximately 30ml purulent collection in right iliac fossa). Complete appendectomy performed. Thorough peritoneal lavage with 2 liters warm normal saline. 14Fr surgical drain placed in right iliac fossa for drainage. Hemostasis achieved. Ports closed in layers.
procedure.intraop_findings: Perforated appendix with gangrenous changes. Localized abscess containing 30ml pus in right iliac fossa. No generalized peritonitis. Appendix adherent to cecum and ileum - adhesiolysis performed.

postop_course.day0: Patient shifted to recovery room post-surgery. Vitals stable. Started on IV antibiotics (Inj. Ceftriaxone 1g BD + Inj. Metronidazole 500mg TDS). IV fluid resuscitation continued. Pain management with IV analgesics. NPO status maintained initially. Drain output: 50ml serosanguinous fluid. Patient monitored in ward.
postop_course.day1: Post-op day 1 (11/10): Patient afebrile, vitals stable. Drain output: 40ml serous fluid. Started on oral sips of water. Mobilized to chair. Pain score 4/10, managed with oral analgesics. No signs of peritonitis or wound infection.
postop_course.day2: Post-op day 2 (12/10): Drain output minimal (20ml). Started on soft diet, tolerating well. Walking independently. Drain removed as output <30ml and serous. Wound sites clean and dry. IV antibiotics continued.
postop_course.day3: Post-op day 3 (13/10): Patient comfortable. Tolerating regular diet. Afebrile. Surgical wounds healing well. IV antibiotics completed 72 hours. Switched to oral antibiotics (Tab. Amoxicillin-Clavulanate 625mg TDS). Bowel sounds present.
postop_course.day4: Post-op day 4 (14/10): Patient completely comfortable. All wounds clean and dry. Tolerating diet well. Ambulatory. Declared medically fit for discharge with oral antibiotics.

complications: Intraoperative finding of perforated appendix with localized abscess - not a post-operative complication but unanticipated pathology requiring modified surgical approach (peritoneal lavage and drain placement). This necessitated extended IV antibiotic therapy (72 hours) and extended hospital stay (4 days instead of planned 3 days).
condition_at_discharge: Stable, afebrile (temperature 98.2°F), pain well controlled (VAS 2/10), tolerating oral diet, all surgical wounds clean and dry, drain site healing well, ambulatory without assistance.

discharge_medications.name: Tab. Amoxicillin-Clavulanate 625mg
discharge_medications.dosage: 1 tablet three times daily after food
discharge_medications.purpose: Complete antibiotic course for infection control

discharge_medications.name: Tab. Metronidazole 400mg
discharge_medications.dosage: 1 tablet three times daily after food

schedule: Day 7 post-surgery (17/10/2025): Wound check and suture removal
activity_dos: Keep surgical wounds clean and dry
activity_donts: Avoid strenuous exercise or gym for 3 weeks
Do not wet surgical wounds for 48 hours
warning_signs: Severe abdominal pain not relieved by medications
Redness, swelling, or discharge from surgical wounds
Unable to pass stools for >3 days

future_treatment_plan: No further surgical intervention required. Complete course of antibiotics. Follow-up for wound healing assessment. Gradual return to normal activities over 3 weeks. No dietary restrictions after discharge.
